Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Molecular Diagnostics and Biological Control of Disease in Farmed Channel Catfish
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is aimed at developing an effective, inexpensive, safe means of controlling diseases in farm-raised catfish. One of the biggest problems in farm-raised catfish is disease that occurs in commercial ponds. Scientists at Auburn University discovered strains of natural bacteria that can be applied to fish feed to control the most common diseases. Lucigen is developing rapid, simple tests capable of detecting these diseases before the fish get sick. The goal is to combine these ideas to develop commercial products to rapidly diagnose and treat the most common catfish diseases.

The broader impacts of this research are 1) the preservation of an important industry in economically disadvantaged regions of the rural southeastern US and 2) protection of an increasingly important food source. Since yields of most wild-caught fish are declining, farmed fish are becoming an important food source and an important industry throughout the world. Fish diseases in aquaculture ponds cause losses of up to half the fish before harvest, costing billions of dollars worldwide, and there is no satisfactory means of controlling most of these outbreaks. Antibiotics, vaccines, chemicals or controlled feeding are all prohibitively expensive, harmful to human and environmental health and/or bad for yields. The detection and control of catfish diseases, the immediate focus of this project, addresses the $20-30M in annual losses caused by disease. Longer term, similar biological control systems should be applicable to other fish species in the US and the rest of the world.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT: This project addresses a growing problem of infectious disease in both aquaculture and traditional land-based agriculture. In worst cases, infectious diseases can have a devastating effect on food production. One way to limit the spread of pathogens is to provide tests that can be used for early detection at penside or pondside so that carriers can be isolated before they infect the rest of the herd. We have developed rapid (30 minute) tests that have performance comparable to lab-based tests, but can be performed away from the lab and the electrical grid. This is possible due to the availability of a new enzyme developed at Lucigen and its formatting for ease of use. To detect a viral or bacterial pathogen, sample blood or saliva can be introduced directly to a dry formulated test mix and incubated at 70C for 30 minutes. The test is then introduced to a device that produces a line if the test is positive. Tests at by academic researchers show the test to be highly sensitive and highly specific. We are developing tests for pathogens affecting salmon, hogs and cattle, These tests should be applicable for use by an operator of a fish, cattle or swine operation and should provide rapid actionable information to the operation.

This is possible due to the availability of a new enzyme developed at Lucigen and its formatting for ease of use.
